Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7090

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackageReferences package dependencies ignore contentFiles's copyToOutput" (#8086) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Remove the content above here and fill out details below.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):
NuGet.exe -  4.9 
VS UI - 15.9.11

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.9.3.5777

VS version (if appropriate): 15.9.11

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): Win 10

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create two Nuspecs with the following details:
Assets Package
`<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<package>
  <metadata>
    <id>Awesome.Assets</id>
    <version>1.0.0.0</version>
    <authors>John Doe</authors>
    <owners>John Doe</owners>
    <requireLicenseAcceptance>false</requireLicenseAcceptance>
    <description>Awesome Assets to be consumed</description>
    <copyright>John Doe Copyright</copyright>
    <dependencies />
   <contentFiles>
    <files include="**/*" buildAction="None" copyToOutput="true" />
   </contentFiles>
  </metadata>
  <files>
    <file src="Assets\**\*" target="contentFiles\any\any\Assets" />
  </files>
</package>`

Dependency Package
`<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<package>
  <metadata>
    <id>Awesome</id>
    <version>1.0.0.0</version>
    <authors>John Doe</authors>
    <owners>John Doe</owners>
    <requireLicenseAcceptance>false</requireLicenseAcceptance>

    <copyright>John Doe Copyright</copyright>

      <dependency id="Awesome.Assets" version="1.0.0.0" />
    </dependencies>
  </metadata>
  <files>
    <file src="Awesome.dll" target="lib\net461" />
   </files>
</package>`
2. Pack the packages with NuGet.exe to generate your needed packages. 
3. Launch VS2017 and start a new C#project (best to do .Net 4.6.1) per settings above.
4. Inside the VS2017 properties, verify that you are using ProjectReferences as the default package management format
5. Right click your new project and select Manage NuGet Package...
6. Navigate/setup the ability to install your new packages but only install the Awesome package.
7. Note that the content files from Awesome.Assets do not get installed or get pushed to the bin directory as you may expect.

The only way that these asset files get pushed to the directory is if you install the Awesome.Assets package. There is no way to force these files to be pushed and a consumer is going to have to know that they need to install the Awesome.Assets package or do more manual steps to include the files via their csproj.

Is this as designed or am I missing something? This question seemed to be asked in https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7153 but the answer doesn't seem to fit this question exactly.

Thank you for your time!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "SkipDuplicate warning frequency for v2 file system pushes" (#8083) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
I recently added the -skipduplicate option to NuGet.exe which works differently depending on v2/v3 file system pushes and server pushes. The v2 file system push is special because it already overwrites duplicates without an error, therefore if a user specifies it in that situation, I output a message that says we ignored it. Currently that repeats for every push (1, 10, or 100+) and the discussion is whether it should work that way or just show once. 

I think it's acceptable since it makes it makes it easier for the user to see their option did nothing, discourages using it for this scenario, should be a rarely used scenario (option is newly introduced), other things are similarly verbose. For a verbosity example: if I push 100 packages to a server that already exist, today I will see output repeated for all 100 of them: "Pushing package xyz", HTTP Put, HTTP Conflict, "error: Response status code does not indicate success: 409 (Conflict)."

NuGet product used: NuGet.exe 

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Use nuget.exe to push a directory of .nupkgs to a v2 file repository with the -SkipDuplicate option. 

2. A warning will appear for each of the .nupkgs that says that SkipDuplicate doesn't do anything for this type of push. 
"The option to skip duplicates is not currently supported for this type of push."

## Other suggested things

- One warning to be shown either at the beginning or end of the output rather than N warnings.

- Cancel the push entirely when providing this option in this context.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Breaking change in IObjectWriter" (#8080) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Members were added to a public interface in this commit: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/commit/32d984b377fef71ea20cf47da26e678c67883879#diff-80bb91cd6c8952511294d414a7e387b4

That's a breaking change for anyone implementing that interface.  I hit it in my build task used by CoreFx to generate runtime.json: https://github.com/dotnet/arcade/pull/2664/files

Typically the way you avoid this is to create a new interface instead of modifying the existing one.  Alternatively, don't use interfaces and instead define abstract classes and add new members as virtual methods with implementations.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget list & add commands are being deprecated in 5.0" (#34) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Tracking Issue(s):
* Deprecate ambiguous nuget.exe commands in 5.0 [#7753](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7753)
  * Deprecate nuget.exe add command [#7923](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7923)
  * Rename nuget.exe list to nuget.exe search [#7912](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7912)

The following commands are being deprecated because these are cause of confusion due to their nomenclature and/or other related commands that already exist:
* [`nuget list`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-list): Currently displays a list of packages from a given source
  * This will be replaced by an equivalent command **`nuget search`** which will be later enhanced with more capabilities as we make progress with or [search improvements](nvmd got it: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6371​​​​​​​).
* [`nuget add`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-add): Currently adds a specified package to a non-HTTP package source (a folder or UNC path) in a hierarchical layout, wherein folders are created for the package ID and version number. 
  * This will be replaced by overloading **`nuget push`** command.

> These commands will be deprecated i.e. there will be a warning on usage of these commands in 5.0 so that in future releases these commands can be discontinued.
